#Text=5. Case Study Details
#Text=This case study focuses on one of the UK ’s largest water utility companies ( UC ) .
#Text=Project numbers and their variation in size , technical work content , and value indicate the challenging complexity of the water programme .
#Text=The projects vary in technical work content since different types of capital infrastructure are dealt with , e.g. , pumping stations , reservoirs , and pipeline renewal .
#Text=Project values range from less than £2 million to £15 million .
#Text=In addition , complexity stems from the involvement of a sizeable network of organisations , such as major contractors , subcontractors , suppliers , consultants , and regulatory institutions .

#Text=Because the water programme typically engages with multiple stakeholders and is a long-term endeavour , effective interorganisational relationships between the water company and its major first tier contractors are important for programme performance .
#Text=In delivering its capital programme , UC chose to adopt a partnering approach with its main contractors .

#Text=The collaborative network studied here comprises the utility company ( UC ) and its main eight contractors ( CTs ) , with the UC adopting a programme management approach to working with its CTs .
#Text=UC management looks to design contracts to encourage competition between partners and to stimulate innovation .

#Text=They change organisational structures frequently , particularly for each AMP cycle , as the regulator rewards companies for introducing managerial innovation as a source of “ efficiency saving ” .
#Text=UC managers believe the company ’s success relies heavily on partnership with its tier 1 contractors .
#Text=A CT is typically formed by a partnership between a design company and a civil construction company , an arrangement with what could be termed tier 2 suppliers .
#Text=In successive cycles of asset management programmes , UC has employed a different mix of tier 1 contractors .
#Text=These changes stem from Ofwat encouraging a “ shake up ” in each AMP .

#Text=Two major changes were instituted at the start of the studied programme : ( 1 ) key personnel from all nine organisations were co-located in a newly acquired multistorey office block to form a newly created Asset Delivery Unit ( ADU ) and ( 2 ) project work was organised into five streams containing projects of a similar technical nature , under two higher level “ production units ” .
#Text=The project grouping determines the work allocation to stream members and establishes key relationships between employees .
#Text=Each stream has a UC manager who was also in charge of lower-level work allocations by batch and project .
#Text=Contractors operate in different numbers of streams , ranging from one to four streams ( see
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=) ; however , individuals are often restricted to working on one stream or sometimes two .
#Text=Some contractors have prior relationships with the UC from previous AMPs .

#Text=Collaboration between contractors is expected across both production units and all five streams as part of the performance criteria established as a response to incentives from the regulatory body .
#Text=Production Unit 1 comprises streams 2 , 3 , and 5 , while Production Unit 2 is made up of streams 1 and 4 .
#Text=A stream level analysis , amongst others , was applied in the research to investigate the connections among the nine organisations ( UC and the eight CTs ) .
#Text=In
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=, each contractor is anonymised by using a capital letter ( A – H ) , while each stream is represented using a number ( 1 – 5 ) .
#Text=The combination of eight contractors with five streams of work adds complexity to the analysis of relationships .
#Text=For instance , contractor G is assigned to streams 1 , 2 , 4 , and 5 while contractors A , B , C , D , and F work for only one stream .
#Text=Each stream is independent from each other but related in the programme .
#Text=Furthermore , prior association with UC varies to a large degree .

#Text=Contractors B and D are new to working with UC on a programme for this cycle , whereas contractors G and E had collaborative relationships with UC for 15 years through three programme cycles of association .
